When we decide that we want to change the behavior of spec operations like `toFixed` do we comment or rename them to say that they're legacy?
content.formatted_body: When we decide that we want to change the behavior of spec operations like toFixed do we comment or rename them to say that they're legacy?

content.body: If we don't, would it be worthwhile to do that so we don't accidentally slip in new uses in the future? Or we could have a spec linter rule, idk if such a tool exists?
yeah, probably we should rename the existing ones and add new stricter ones
or add a "looseness" parameter, I guess
Are there other changes that we would make to Temporal if we wanted to apply all the conventions?
not doing any coercions at all :)
which would save a lot of tests, among other things
I meant for the conventions that we already adopted
we already adopted "don't do any coercions"
Oh right
I am in favor of applying this to Temporal
I think it is much more likely that we can apply this change to 402.
We aren’t talking about 262 overall, just those three methods
FWIW for Temporal.Duration we already rejected non-integral inputs because of people putting in values like `Temporal.Duration.from({ hours: 1.5 })`
content.formatted_body: FWIW for Temporal.Duration we already rejected non-integral inputs because of people putting in values like Temporal.Duration.from({ hours: 1.5 })

content.body: I'm open to going back and changing other things like `roundingIncrement`, `fractionalSecondDigits`, and `Temporal.PlainDate.from({ year: 2024.5, month: 7.5, day: 29.5 })` to reject non-integral inputs but I'd like us to explicitly approve that now, rather than me coming back to a following meeting with a PR
content.formatted_body: I'm open to going back and changing other things like roundingIncrement, fractionalSecondDigits, and Temporal.PlainDate.from({ year: 2024.5, month: 7.5, day: 29.5 }) to reject non-integral inputs but I'd like us to explicitly approve that now, rather than me coming back to a following meeting with a PR

I'm open to going back and changing other things like roundingIncrement, fractionalSecondDigits, and Temporal.PlainDate.from({ year: 2024.5, month: 7.5, day: 29.5 }) to reject non-integral inputs but I'd like us to explicitly approve that now, rather than me coming back to a following meeting with a PR
What about the other conventions?

content.body: I don't know off the top of my head how much deviation there is from the other conventions, I'd have to check

IMO, it makes sense that year, month, and day require integral inputs, but not hour/minute/second. Given one of the goals of Temporal is to make date and time math easier, not being able to write `Temporal.Duration.from({ hours: 1.5 })` is unfortunate.
content.formatted_body: IMO, it makes sense that year, month, and day require integral inputs, but not hour/minute/second. Given one of the goals of Temporal is to make date and time math easier, not being able to write Temporal.Duration.from({ hours: 1.5 }) is unfortunate.

content.body: Well I was wondering if ptomato had an opinion on the “not coercing at all” one with respect to Temporal

content.body: Rbuckton: you are making a very different feature request from this coercion discussion. Probably this is best for the temporal v2 bucket
